newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - UK retail sales to slow in September.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - UK retail sales to slow in September.

text.p: British retail sales are expected to have slowed in September but would not disguise the fact the trend in consumer spending is firmly upwards, economists said.
A Reuter poll of economists produced a consensus forecast that sales will fall 0.1 percent in September, leaving them 3.9 percent higher year-on-year.
But given that sales shot up by 1.0 percent in August and anecdotal evidence suggests consumers are spending freely again in October, there is no question of a prolonged slowdown, economists said.
"It is becoming increasingly clear that the long-awaited pick-up in retail fortunes has arrived," said Philip Uglow, economist at Union Plc.

But as the Confederation of British Industry's distributive trades survey for September showed retail sales grew at a slower pace than in August, as did the British Retail Consortium's sales monitor, there could be a temporary hiatus, he said.
The BRC survey showed retail sales up 5.2 percent year-on-year in September, compared with growth of 6.9 percent in August. "Both imply a small fall in official sales in September," Uglow said.
David Philpotts, UK economist at Schroders, noted that weekly sales figures from stores and supermarkets group John Lewis Partnership, had also waned a little in September.

"We look for a small monthly decline but this will not negate the upward trend," he said, adding that John Lewis and weekly M0 money supply figures so far in October suggested sales have picked up again.
Michael Saunders, UK economist at Salomon Brothers, said rocketing clothing and footwear prices in September were likely to have forced sales volumes lower in that sector.
Retail price figures, released earlier this month, showed clothing and footwear prices leapt by 5.2 percent last month, the biggest jump since records began in 1947.
"There are several signs that retail sales slipped back in September," Saunders said, highlighting evidence from the CBI, BRC and John Lewis.
"Even with a modest dip in spending in September, however, the trend in third-quarter retail sales is likely to remain reasonably buoyant."
He forecast a 0.3 percent fall in September sales, more extreme than the market consensus, but said even that would leave third quarter sales 0.9 percent higher than in the second quarter.
